articles.headline: Want to Know What’s Bedeviling Biden? TikTok Economics May Hold Clues.
articles.snippet: Economic despair dominates social media as young people fret about the cost of living. It offers a snapshot of the challenges facing Democrats ahead of the 2024 election.
articles.abstract: Economic despair dominates social media as young people fret about the cost of living. It offers a snapshot of the challenges facing Democrats ahead of the 2024 election.
articles.lead_paragraph: Look at economic data, and you’d think that young voters would be riding high right now. Unemployment remains low. Job opportunities are plentiful. Inequality is down, wage growth is finally beating inflation, and the economy has expanded rapidly this year.
articles.byline: By Jeanna Smialek and Jim Tankersley

articles.headline: How Bad Is Antisemitism Online? It’s Increasingly Hard to Know.
articles.snippet: People who study social media say the conflict between Israel and Hamas has underscored the need for better data transparency from platforms.
articles.abstract: People who study social media say the conflict between Israel and Hamas has underscored the need for better data transparency from platforms.
articles.lead_paragraph: As the Israel-Hamas war flooded social media with violent content, false information and a seemingly limitless swell of opinions, lawmakers and users have accused platforms like TikTok and Facebook of promoting biased posts.
articles.byline: By Tiffany Hsu and Sapna Maheshwari

articles.headline: A Journey Into Northern Gaza: Ruins, Wreckage and Darkness
articles.snippet: New York Times journalists traveled with an Israeli military convoy to catch a rare glimpse of conditions in wartime Gaza. They saw houses flattened like playing cards and a city utterly disfigured.
articles.abstract: New York Times journalists traveled with an Israeli military convoy to catch a rare glimpse of conditions in wartime Gaza. They saw houses flattened like playing cards and a city utterly disfigured.
articles.lead_paragraph: When a group of international journalists arrived at the southern fringe of Gaza City early Friday morning, riding in the back of an Israeli army jeep, we struggled to orient ourselves amid the ruins, the wreckage and the darkness.
articles.byline: By Patrick Kingsley and Daniel Berehulak

articles.headline: Often Dismissed, Sideline Reporters Now Deal With Fabrication Fallout
articles.snippet: Charissa Thompson’s statement that she had made up reports during N.F.L. games on Fox left many of her counterparts aghast.
articles.abstract: Charissa Thompson’s statement that she had made up reports during N.F.L. games on Fox left many of her counterparts aghast.
articles.lead_paragraph: Since Thursday afternoon, those in the sports media industry, particularly women, have been talking about one thing: that the prominent broadcaster Charissa Thompson had casually volunteered in an interview that she had made up reports while working as a sideline reporter.
articles.byline: By Jenny Vrentas and Kevin Draper

articles.headline: OpenAI’s Board Pushes Out Sam Altman, Its High-Profile C.E.O.
articles.snippet: Mira Murati, who previously served as chief technology officer, has been named interim chief executive.
articles.abstract: Mira Murati, who previously served as chief technology officer, has been named interim chief executive.
articles.lead_paragraph: Sam Altman, the high-profile chief executive of OpenAI, who became the face of the tech industry’s artificial intelligence boom, was pushed out of the company by its board of directors, OpenAI said in a blog post on Friday afternoon.

articles.headline: Advertisers Flee X as Outcry Over Musk’s Endorsement of Antisemitic Post Grows
articles.snippet: Disney, Apple, Paramount and Lionsgate halted marketing on X, formerly Twitter, as Elon Musk faced a furor over antisemitic abuse on his social media platform.
articles.abstract: Disney, Apple, Paramount and Lionsgate halted marketing on X, formerly Twitter, as Elon Musk faced a furor over antisemitic abuse on his social media platform.
articles.lead_paragraph: The blowback over Elon Musk’s endorsement of an antisemitic conspiracy theory on X gathered steam on Friday, as several major advertisers on his social media platform cut off their spending after his comments.
articles.byline: By Ryan Mac, Brooks Barnes and Tiffany Hsu

articles.headline: How to Keep Your Bank From Closing All Your Accounts
articles.snippet: Banks have suddenly shut down the accounts of scores of customers. Here’s how you can avoid becoming one of them.
articles.abstract: Banks have suddenly shut down the accounts of scores of customers. Here’s how you can avoid becoming one of them.
articles.lead_paragraph: Having a checking account is a privilege, not a right, but most people forget this until they lose access to their accounts.

articles.headline: Why Is the College Board Pushing to Expand Advanced Placement?
articles.snippet: This year, taxpayers paid the nonprofit at least $90 million for A.P. tests that many students failed.
articles.abstract: This year, taxpayers paid the nonprofit at least $90 million for A.P. tests that many students failed.
articles.lead_paragraph: For the past two decades, the College Board has moved aggressively to expand the number of high school students taking Advanced Placement courses and tests — in part by pitching the program to low-income students and the schools that serve them.

articles.headline: Dubai’s Costly Water World
articles.snippet: The city has spent billions of dollars to provide fresh water to its residents and tourist attractions, but experts say the efforts are straining the Persian Gulf’s natural resources.
articles.abstract: The city has spent billions of dollars to provide fresh water to its residents and tourist attractions, but experts say the efforts are straining the Persian Gulf’s natural resources.
articles.lead_paragraph: For a desert city, Dubai appears like a water wonderland. Visitors can scuba dive in the world’s deepest pool or ski inside a megamall where penguins play in freshly made snow. A fountain — billed as the world’s largest — sprays more than 22,000 gallons of water into the air, synchronized to music from surrounding speakers.

articles.headline: Sex Workers Have Been Shunned by Banks, Even When Their Work Is Legal
articles.snippet: Financial service companies often avoid what they deem high-risk industries like adult entertainment. When workers lose their accounts, they are left with few options.
articles.abstract: Financial service companies often avoid what they deem high-risk industries like adult entertainment. When workers lose their accounts, they are left with few options.
articles.lead_paragraph: Bella Cummins has run Bella’s Hacienda Ranch, her Nevada brothel, for nearly four decades — and for four decades, she’s been shunned by much of the banking industry.

articles.headline: Colombia to Sterilize Pablo Escobar’s ‘Cocaine Hippos’
articles.snippet: The drug kingpin brought four hippos to his estate in the 1980s. Officials estimate that about 170 now roam Colombia, and say the population must be controlled to protect the country’s ecosystem.
articles.abstract: The drug kingpin brought four hippos to his estate in the 1980s. Officials estimate that about 170 now roam Colombia, and say the population must be controlled to protect the country’s ecosystem.
articles.lead_paragraph: When the Colombian drug lord Pablo Escobar was killed in 1993, most of the animals he had imported as pets — zebras, giraffes, kangaroos and rhinoceroses — died or were transferred to zoos.

articles.headline: The War Turns Gaza Into a ‘Graveyard’ for Children
articles.snippet: Thousands of children have been killed in the enclave since the Israeli assault began, officials in Gaza say. The Israeli military says it takes “all feasible precautions” to avoid civilian deaths.
articles.abstract: Thousands of children have been killed in the enclave since the Israeli assault began, officials in Gaza say. The Israeli military says it takes “all feasible precautions” to avoid civilian deaths.
articles.lead_paragraph: Barefoot and weeping, Khaled Joudeh, 9, hurried toward the dozens of bodies wrapped in white burial shrouds, blankets and rugs outside the overcrowded morgue.

articles.headline: Sam Altman Is Said to Be Discussing Return to OpenAI With Company’s Board
articles.snippet: Mr. Altman was forced out of the artificial intelligence start-up on Friday, leading to an outcry from his supporters and the company’s investors.
articles.abstract: Mr. Altman was forced out of the artificial intelligence start-up on Friday, leading to an outcry from his supporters and the company’s investors.
articles.lead_paragraph: Sam Altman and Greg Brockman, two top executives at OpenAI who left the company after a dramatic board meeting on Friday, are talking again with board members about returning to the artificial intelligence start-up, two people with knowledge of the matter said.
articles.byline: By Cade Metz, Mike Isaac and Erin Griffith

articles.headline: The Invisible War in Ukraine Being Fought Over Radio Waves
articles.snippet: Using electromagnetic waves to flummox and follow smarter weapons has become a critical part of the cat-and-mouse game between Ukraine and Russia. The United States, China and others have taken note.
articles.abstract: Using electromagnetic waves to flummox and follow smarter weapons has become a critical part of the cat-and-mouse game between Ukraine and Russia. The United States, China and others have taken note.
articles.lead_paragraph: The drones began crashing on Ukraine’s front lines, with little explanation.
articles.byline: By Paul Mozur and Aaron Krolik

articles.headline: A Jan. 6 Defendant Pleads His Case to the Son Who Turned Him In
articles.snippet: The Capitol attacks ruptured their mutual trust. In the weeks before Brian Mock’s sentencing, could he mend the divide with his son A.J.?
articles.abstract: The Capitol attacks ruptured their mutual trust. In the weeks before Brian Mock’s sentencing, could he mend the divide with his son A.J.?
articles.lead_paragraph: The trial was over and the verdict was in, but Brian Mock, 44, kept going back through the evidence, trying to make his case to the one person whose opinion he valued most. He sat at his kitchen table in rural Wisconsin next to his son, 21-year-old A.J. Mock, and opened a video on his laptop. He leaned into the screen and traced his finger over the image of the U.S. Capitol building, looked through clouds of tear gas and smoke and then pointed toward the center of a riotous crowd.
articles.byline: By Eli Saslow and Erin Schaff

articles.headline: A 30-Year Trap: The Problem With America’s Weird Mortgages
articles.snippet: One big reason the U.S. housing market is broken: Owners don’t want to give up their cushy old loans.
articles.abstract: One big reason the U.S. housing market is broken: Owners don’t want to give up their cushy old loans.
articles.lead_paragraph: Buying a home was hard before the pandemic. Somehow, it keeps getting harder.

articles.headline: For Years, Two Men Shuttled Messages Between Israel and Hamas. No Longer.
articles.snippet: Since 2006, Gershon Baskin, an Israeli peace activist, and Ghazi Hamad, a Hamas official, maintained a secret back channel between Gaza and Israel. Then Oct. 7 happened.
articles.abstract: Since 2006, Gershon Baskin, an Israeli peace activist, and Ghazi Hamad, a Hamas official, maintained a secret back channel between Gaza and Israel. Then Oct. 7 happened.
articles.lead_paragraph: For 17 years, on and off, two men maintained a secret line of communication between Israel and Hamas, the armed Palestinian group that opposes Israel’s existence.

articles.headline: Rosalynn Carter, First Lady and a Political Partner, Dies at 96
articles.snippet: She helped propel Jimmy Carter from rural Georgia to the White House and became the most politically active first lady since Eleanor Roosevelt.
articles.abstract: She helped propel Jimmy Carter from rural Georgia to the White House and became the most politically active first lady since Eleanor Roosevelt.
articles.lead_paragraph: Rosalynn Carter, a true life partner to Jimmy Carter who helped propel him from rural Georgia to the White House in a single decade and became the most politically active first lady since Eleanor Roosevelt, died on Sunday in Plains, Ga. She was 96.

articles.headline: Argentina Elects Javier Milei in Victory for Far Right
articles.snippet: Argentina’s next president is a libertarian economist whose brash style and embrace of conspiracy theories has parallels with those of Donald J. Trump.
articles.abstract: Argentina’s next president is a libertarian economist whose brash style and embrace of conspiracy theories has parallels with those of Donald J. Trump.
articles.lead_paragraph: Argentines on Sunday chose Javier Milei, a far-right libertarian who has drawn comparisons to Donald J. Trump, as their next president, a lurch to the right for a nation struggling under an economic crisis and a sign of the enduring strength of the global far right.

articles.headline: Infants Moved From ‘Death Zone’ Hospital That Israel Says Was Hamas Hideout
articles.snippet: U.N. officials said 31 premature babies in precarious health were evacuated from Al-Shifa Hospital to a hospital further south in Gaza.
articles.abstract: U.N. officials said 31 premature babies in precarious health were evacuated from Al-Shifa Hospital to a hospital further south in Gaza.
articles.lead_paragraph: Four days after it was seized by Israeli troops, the Gaza Strip’s largest hospital has become a “death zone,” the World Health Organization said, as 31 premature babies in extremely precarious health there were evacuated on Sunday.
articles.byline: By Vivian Yee, Vivek Shankar, Isabel Kershner and Michael Levenson

articles.headline: ‘Lost Time for No Reason’: How Driverless Taxis Are Stressing Cities
articles.snippet: In San Francisco and Austin, Texas, where passengers can hail self-driving vehicles, the cars have added to the workloads of city employees.
articles.abstract: In San Francisco and Austin, Texas, where passengers can hail self-driving vehicles, the cars have added to the workloads of city employees.
articles.lead_paragraph: Around 2 a.m. on March 19, Adam Wood, a San Francisco firefighter on duty, received a 911 call and raced to the city’s Mission neighborhood to help a male who was having a medical emergency. After loading the patient into an ambulance, a black-and-white car pulled up and blocked the path.

articles.headline: Between Israelis and Palestinians, a Lethal Psychological Chasm Grows
articles.snippet: In a conflict marked by complete incomprehension on both sides, the ability to see each other as human has been lost.
articles.abstract: In a conflict marked by complete incomprehension on both sides, the ability to see each other as human has been lost.
articles.lead_paragraph: Eight years after the foundation of the state of Israel, Moshe Dayan, the chief of staff of the Israeli military, stood close to the Gaza border to pronounce a eulogy for a 21-year-old Israeli security officer slain by Palestinian and Egyptian assailants.

articles.headline: In Ukraine’s Slowed-Down War, Death Comes as Quickly as Ever
articles.snippet: Ukraine is facing continual eastern assaults from Russian forces at a bloody cost for both sides, even as the lines on the map barely move.
articles.abstract: Ukraine is facing continual eastern assaults from Russian forces at a bloody cost for both sides, even as the lines on the map barely move.
articles.lead_paragraph: The agony came in waves as the wounded Ukrainian soldier in the back of the ambulance slipped in and out of consciousness. The driver, hurtling past cratered fields on roads thick with mud, was racing to escape Russian artillery fire north of the city of Avdiivka, while hoping he was not spotted by drones.
articles.byline: By Marc Santora and Tyler Hicks

articles.headline: The Winners and Losers of OpenAI’s Wild Weekend
articles.snippet: It is hard to see the past few days as anything but a big loss for the A.I. company.
articles.abstract: It is hard to see the past few days as anything but a big loss for the A.I. company.
articles.lead_paragraph: For a while this weekend, it looked as if Sam Altman might return as a conquering hero to OpenAI, the company whose board had fired him as chief executive on Friday.
